text: I'm actually, this is gonna stay, I think I'm gonna try to, because it's 20 minutes, I'm gonna bounce through a lot of ideas and sort of hopefully peg them for more detailed, involved discussions during sort of workshops and stuff this afternoon, rather than trying to go really deep into anything in particular.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: With that in mind, I'm going to talk about complexity in social and economic systems as sort of a leading point.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the reason that we have sort of these complex emergent behaviors in our socio-technical systems is that we are fundamentally modifying the environment that we participate in.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Actually, there's some interesting analogies to discussion of sort of biological evolution where our bacteria was functionally changing the environment, and that changing environment changed the fitness landscape for the participation in that environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we're actually doing this in sort of macro human scale by engineering on the world and inventing things and building new technologies and fundamentally modifying the means with which we interact with each other and our environment, which in turn our social and economic behaviors adapt to.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So this is sort of behavioral evolution.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I'm going to be focusing on this from a sort of social behavior and social ecological perspective.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But I always find it fun to talk about how the sort of complex feedback dynamic emerges in these sort of what I would call cyber-physical systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And anyway, this is sort of the main entry point.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We have this overlap between the sort of temporal dynamics, how we behave, how that behavior changes the environment, and how in turn the changed environment changes our behaviors.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The sort of paradigms for complexity in engineering are not particularly new.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I like to point out that the socio-technical systems paradigm was introduced in the 50s.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The sort of second order cybernetics and the discussion of sort of control systems and the way in which our, the way we organize our societies and organize systems becomes part of those systems itself is sort of introduced in the 70s and was very popular in the sort of
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I don't know, like late Cold War, post-Soviet application of engineering to sort of human systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And now actually we have something that is a little bit newer.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I like the term cyber-physical systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: They are things like our power grids where there are the economic loads put on the grid, the physical network infrastructure,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: the plants and various other forms of sort of business entities that actually collectively, you know, source power, source materials, source labor, like all the way down to the economics at the individual consumption of power level.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Those systems are highly networked.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And in fact, we see things like cascade failures when sort of part of a
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: power system goes down the loads get shifted and you can actually have the same systems that make the resilient in the short term can make it fragile because you sort of pick up the loads that were dropped and if that over sort of overloads the system then you see more things go down these are actually some of our best physical networked
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: sort of multi-layer systems that exist today and I think it behooves us to study them as part of our sort of what I would say more social system studies as I get into sort of decentralized organizations.

speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And there are lots of cases where we look at one or two of these things together, but when in our increasingly interconnected systems, it's very difficult to fraction them apart from each other and still have a coherent view of what I'll call a generalized ecology.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Like if this is a social and economic ecology, then the environment is defined by technology and the physical environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But as the rate of change of the technological or physical systems rises, it becomes less appropriate to separate the time scales.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so we kind of have to reason them as systems that are co-evolving between social, economic, and technological and physical.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: sort of evolutionary dynamics like, and as we get down into this trusted computation and durable data, now we're talking about the way in which sort of novel information technologies are allowing us to sort of program these environments because we have cryptographically guaranteed execution of code.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is a bit like writing your own rules of a mini universe.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You're saying,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You are allowed to do this and not that.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And if you attempt to do something that the system doesn't allow, it just doesn't happen.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Unlike our traditional economic systems, where basically you do anything that you get away with, you pre prescribe what you can and cannot do in these environments and an attempt to violate those sort of coded natural laws breaks.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But what's really tricky about this is that you don't really do this at a very human intuitive level to make it work well.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: you're generally working in very abstract spaces.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You're defining
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: you're defining the very notion of what is possible at an abstract level, and it backs up to the fact that you have durable, the last layer is what I call durable data or trustworthy state information, which means that these computations can be state-dependent, which is what gives them real-world-like properties.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If you just have trusted computation but computation isn't able to write or read a trustworthy state,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: then you don't get the capacity to sort of embed state-dependent dynamics, to internalize externalities.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You want things to have the same property of the physical world.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If I want to move the state of the system, I need to expend some energy or expend some resource.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I can't simply arbitrage an environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I have to actually pay the price of moving it, and therefore I only change the system insofar as I really...
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: you know, the cost is worth it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so there's this Pareto response that says, yeah, OK, I wanted to move the system, but I don't want to move it ad infinitum because moving the system costs me energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And as long as my capacity is finite, I can't diverge the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If we want to talk a lot more math later during breakouts, I'm happy to do it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is a conceptual framework for being able to go from basically to create sort of programmable environments where you actually have reasonable predictability of emergent properties, but the
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: point here is that emergent properties are not defined as equilibrium in the sense of exactly this will happen, rather they're quite the opposite.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: They live in much higher orders, like if the system can be changed according to a certain set of rules, that means it has a set of reachable spaces, and you're actually just restricting those reachable spaces.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that means that you have some underlying universal properties that can be thought of as some
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: we often don't function in a high dimensional space over a part of the space maps to zero or stays within a ball around a set because moving out of that set is costly and that the system is sort of attracted back into that set.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But this isn't a statement about the state, the first order state.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is often a statement about the second or even the third derivative.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's constraining how much the system can move away from a subspace in a highly expanded view of the world.

text: I'm going to talk a little bit more about the technology because one of the reasons I came here today was to try to give this community more knowledge about what this technology stack can do,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: rules that define networks decentralized networks and configurations through which peers interact at the computational level you can form peer-to-peer networks which are essentially communication and computation networks where each peer is essentially provably following the rules of the protocol and their behaviors are not controlled just the rules about what valid behavior is
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the byproduct of that low-level technology is to enable sets of higher-level interaction patterns, which are sort of, if this is computation and communication network, this is sort of social and economic behavior, where what one can do agent to agent here is a property of what this peer-to-peer network exposes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So this gives you the rules of this world and enforces them, and thus individual interactions are, hey, whatever follows the rules, but then collectively those fit into these larger networks of interacting activity, sort of ecologies of behavior, which actually result in emergent properties.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And from a design perspective, you have to basically...
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: make claims about what you want, what you're trying to achieve up here, work backwards through this conceptual stack towards what I can actually build, and roll back up to defining these things and essentially enabling and measuring the extent to which you're achieving your desired properties.

text: We generally approach this using a sort of formal scientific and engineering process, which mixes basically three kinds of science, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We have analytical.

text: I'm working on writing some papers and some tutorials when time's available.

text: But the core sort of high-dimensional representations of systems in abstract mathematical spaces allows you to do computer-aided design, essentially run simulations of those systems and refine your understanding of those systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: and then ultimately implementing things, observing real data, which creates a sort of standard scientific feedback loop, but we're trying to basically understand the implications of our decisions about social and economic rules.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: One of the probably most important points that I make ever is that whenever you're doing this, you are making subjective choices about objective measures.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: There isn't an objective fitness in this sense.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Like people like to,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: reason as if there is one and more often than not you have to pick one to reason and then you have to back out and sensitivity test and understand what is the implication of making that assumption because you don't get to say well this is the social utility of the system like even if you go into social choice theory like there's a million ideas and none of them are inherently right and often they even conflict with each other
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So you have to basically say, I've systematized this social and economic co-evolutionary system, and at various points in the process, I have made subjective choices of objective measures.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so one of the most important parts about being a designer of these kinds of systems is to actually be explicit every time you do this and find ways to A-B test or sensitivity test those assumptions.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So sensitivity test when you parameterize things, A-B test with alternative metrics,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: and repeat the same experiments computationally when possible with different measures and see how robust the results that you've gotten.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So something might, you know, have nice dynamics and converge to an equilibrium under some, and here I mean equilibrium in the sense that there's a low dimensional attractive subspace, not that the whole system somehow converges to something static.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: whether or not those spaces, the behavior patterns, the sort of ultimate emergent non-equilibrium dynamics that have some properties actually are desirable is also subjective.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's a really weird place to be because you're sort of forced to simultaneously objectify, but to do it well you can't actually trust your own objectifications.

text: Anyway, so I'm going to talk a little bit about decentralization and organizations, because I think these terms semantically cause a lot of challenges.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And in order to actually make any meaningful progress on any project, you have to sort of
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: get on the same page.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So I define organizations in terms of networks, and just simply say that you have, it can be multi-scale, but for simplicity, we'll talk about a network of individuals.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: A network of individuals is basically going to say, well, I have some form of interaction with another party, and I have this interconnected web of labor, activity, exchange, trade, whatever, and my organization can be defined as essentially a network of individuals.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I, for the most part, am dealing with sort of open social and economic environments, so an organization might be a community in the sense that we know each other or have people in common, or it might be something more formal like a corporation or a community that you join or have to get permission to join.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: In order to keep something formal and abstract, we're just basically defining them as networks over agents.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And when you have a network over agents, you need to understand what does it mean to have a link, and a link is a function of coordination, and for whatever the context is, we can talk about, well, we want to do something together, whatever it is, and I have some rules, requirements, limitations, whatever, and you do, and then the feasible space of links that we could form between us is basically the overlap between these two things.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And if there's no overlap, then
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We don't link and it's no big deal because the system doesn't require that everybody's linked to everyone.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We just have to have this idea that there's this network formation game embedded in the idea of an organization as a network that determines whether or not we choose to persist a relationship.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that is an abstract concept because all we really want is the graph at this point.

text: You need a specific problem space, a problem to be working on, where this collapses to a specific

text: And the agreement pattern was a multi-party, someone offers to teach, basically,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: puts out a thing that says, I'll teach this class for this much money if so many people sign up, et cetera, et cetera.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And then ultimately, if the conditions are met, it's sort of determined to be sort of an agreement, and at which point reneging it has costs.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01
